div2.stage: Enter a PARASITE and a BOY.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: Of a debauched and unscrupulous fellow am I the Parasite--a Captain, who has brought his mistress with him from Samos. Now he has ordered me to go to her, and make enquiry whether she will pay back the gold, or whether she will depart together with him. You, boy, who have for some time been with her, whichever of these is the house, do you knock. Go to the door forthwith. The BOY goes to knock. Are you coming back from there, you hangdogYou hangdog: "Dierecte." The meaning of this word has been explained in the Notes to the Trinummus.? How the graceless scoundrel does knock! You can gobble up a loaf three feet wide, and yet you don't know how to knock at a door. He calls out and knocks violently. Is there any one in-doors? Hallo! is there any one here? Does any one open this door? Who's coming out?

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: What's the matter? What's this knocking? Why, what the confounded torment possesses you, to be exerting your strength in this fashion on another person's door? You've almost broken the door down. What do you want now?

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: Young gentleman, my respects.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: And my respects. But whom are you looking for?

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: For Bacchis.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: But which of them?

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: Of that I know nothing, only it's Bacchis. In a few words, the Captain, Cleomachus, has sent me to her, either for her to pay back the tyro hundred golden Philippeans, or to go hence this day, together with him, to ElatiaTo Elatia: Elatia was a city of Phocis, a district in the Northern part of Greece..

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: She doesn't go: she says she shan't go. Begone, and take back this message--she loves another person, and not him. Take yourself off from the house.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: You're too hasty.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: And would you know now hasty I am? By my faith, your phiz isn't far off from a mishap; so much are these teeth-crackers looking at his fists longing in my fists.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: aside. So far as I understand his words, 'tis a warning to me, lest he should knock my nut-crackers out of my jaws. To PISTOCLERUS. At your own peril, I'll tell him this.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: I'll tell him that which you bade me.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Who are you? Tell me.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: I'm the skill of his bodySkin of his body: "Integumentum corporis." Literally, "the skin," or "covering of the body." This was probably a nickname for a body. guard, or hanger-on.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: He needs must be a scampish fellow, who has got so worthless a skin.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: He'll be coming here, swollen up with wrath.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: I wish he may burst.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: about to go. Is there anything you want?

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Be off; you must do so this instant.

sp.speaker: PARASITE
sp.p: Good-bye, teeth-cracker. Exit. PISTOC. And you, skin of his body, good-bye! This matter has come to such a point, that what advice to give my friend about his mistress, I know not; who, in his pet, has given up all the gold to his father, and not a coin is there that may be paid to the Captain. But I'll step aside, for the door makes a noise. O, here's Mnesilochus coming out, and pensive, too. He stands apart.

div2.stage: Enter MNESILOCHUS from the house of BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Insolent, of a froward, passionate, ungovernable, inconsiderate disposition, without reason and moderation, am I; without fine principles of rectitude and honor, hard of belief, powerless to control my passions, born of a temper ill-disposed, unamiable and ungracious is my lifeIs my life: "Vivo." Literally "I live," "I exist." In fine, I am that which I could wish others to be. There's not a person more worthless, or more unworthy for the Gods to bless, or for men to love or to associate with. 'Tis more just that I should have enemies than friends--'tis more reasonable that the bad should give me their assistance than the good. There's not a person more deserving of all the reproaches that are befitting worthless men, than I, who have given up to my father the money that was in my power. Could this be believed by any one whatever? Am I not a madman, who have miserably undone myself and the device of Chrysalus?

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: aside. He must now be consoled by me; I'll accost him. Aloud. Hallo, Mnesilochus! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I'm ruined.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant better things!

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I'm ruined.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Won't you hold your tongue, simpleton?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Hold my tongue?

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: You are not now quite right in your senses.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I'm undone. Many sharp and poignant woes are now arising in my breast. Did I not put faith in that accusation? Without any cause was I angry with you.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Come, come, do have a good heart.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Whence have it? A dead man is of more value than I am.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: The Captain's Parasite came here, just now, to fetch the gold hence. I drove the fellow away from this door and from this fair one, and packed him off through my harsh language.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: But of what service is that to me? Wretch that I am, what shall I do? I have nothing; and he certainly will carry her off.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: By my faith, if I had the means, I'd engage not.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I know you'd give it me; I know your ways; and were you not in love, I should now have the very greatest possible confidence in your assistance. At present, you yourself have more than enough of your own business, for me to suppose that you, who are in want yourself; are able to give me any assistance.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Do but hold your tongue: some Divinity will favour us.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS.
sp.p: Nonsense. Moves as if going.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Do stay Takes hold of him.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Why, I see Chrysalus here, your main resource.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: to himself. It's right this man pointing to himself should be worth his weightBe worth his weight: "Auro expendi." Literally, "to be weighed against gold." in gold: it's fair that a statue of gold should be erected for him. For, this day, two exploits have I achieved; with twofold spoils have I been graced. So cleverly have I gulled my elder master this day, that he has been made a fool of. The crafty old blade, by my crafty tricks, have I compelled and constrained to believe me in everything. Then, for the son of the old gentleman, my master here in love, together with whom I drink, with whom I eat and go a-courting, I have procured regal and golden trea sures, that he may take from thence at home, and not go seeking abroad. Those ParmenosThose Parmenos: Syrus and Parmeno were the names of certain crafty intriguing slaves introduced in Comedy. The first occurs as the name of a slave in the Adelphi of Terence; the second in his Eunuchus. and those Syruses, please me not, who filch some two or three minae from their masters. There's nothing more worthless than a servant without skill--worthless, if he has not a breast mightily well-stocked, so that, whenever there is necessity, he may draw his supply from his own breast. No one can be a person well to do unless he understands both how to do good and how to do evil. With rogues he must be a rogue; with thieves let him filch whatever he can. It befits him who is truly wise, to be a person that can shift his very skinShift his very skin: "Vorsipellis." Literally, "a turner of his skin;" similar in meaning to our expression, a "turncoat.". Good with the good let him be, bad with the bad: just as things are, so let him ever frame his humour. But I should like to know how much gold my master has taken for himself, and what he has given up to his father. If he is a prudent person, he has made a HerculesHas made a Hercules: A tenth part of the spoil taken in warfare was devoted to Hercules; and it was believed to ensure prosperity, if persons devoted a tenth of their possessions to the same Divinity of his parent: he has given him the tenth part, and has kept back nine for himself. But, see! the person whom I was looking for; he meets me most opportunely. To MNESILOCHUS. Has any of your money fallen down, my master, that thus, in silence, you are looking down upon the ground? Why do I see you two sad and sorrowful? I like it not; and 'tis not without some reason. Are you going now to give me any answer?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I'm undone, Chrysalus.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Perhaps you took too little of the gold.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: How, a plague, too little? Why, yes, indeed, a very great deal less than too little.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Why the mischief then, simpleton, since by my skill an opportunity was procured for that very purpose, that you might take as much as you pleased, did you thus take it up with the tips of two fingersTwo fingers: He says that when he had the opportunity of gathering up the money by handfuls, he contented himself with taking it only with the tips of his fingers, that is, piece by piece; some would take "digiti duo primores" to mean "the two first fingers of the hand;" that is, the forefinger and thumb. The meaning, either way, will be just the same.? Or, didn't you know how rarely an opportunity of that kind presents itself to a person?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: You are mistaken.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Why, surely, 'tis you yourself that were mistaken, when you dip't your fingers in not deep enough.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I' faith, you'd upbraid me more than now you do, if you knew the matter better. I'm undone.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: My mind is now foreboding further mischief from those words.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I'm ruined.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Because I've given all up to my father, with every particleWith every particle: "Ramentum" properly means the filings of scrapings--"dust and all" "every particle." of it.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Given it up?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Given it up.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What, all?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Every jot.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: We are done for. How came it into your mind to do this deed so foul?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I had a suspicion, Chrysalus, by reason of a charge, that Bacchis and he (pointing to PISTOCLERUS) had been playing me false; for that reason, in my anger, I gave up all the gold to my father.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What did you say to your father when you gave up the gold?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: That I had at once received this gold from his host, Archidemides.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Eh! by that speech you have this day consigned Chrysalus to the torture; for, when he shall set eyes on me, the old gentleman will carry me off that instant to the executioner.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: I've besought my father.

sp.speaker: CERYS.
sp.p: I suppose, to do, in fact, the thing that I was speaking of?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Nay, not to punish you, or to blame you at all on account of this business. And with some difficulty I've prevailed. Now, Chrysalus, this must be your care.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What do you wish should be my care?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: That once again you should make a second inroad upon the old gentleman. Contrive, devise, invent whatever you please; frame your plansFrame your plans: "Conglutina." Literally, "glue the pieces together ", so that this day you may cleverly deceive the old man unawares, and carry off the gold.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: It scarcely seems possible to be done.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Set about it, and you'll easily effect it.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: How the plague "easily," for me, whom he has this moment caught out in a lie? Should I entreat him not to believe me at all, he would not venture even to believe me in that.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Aye, and if you were to hear what things he said about you in my presence.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: That if you were to say that this sun was the sun, he would believe it was the moon, and that that is the night which is now the day.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: By my troth, I'll bamboozle the old chap right well this very day, so that he shan't have said that for nothing.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Now, what would you have us do?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Why, nothing, except that I beg you'll still love on. As for the rest, ask of me as much gold as you please; I'll find it you. Of what use is it for me to have the name of ChrysalusName of Chrysalus: He alludes to his name as derived from the Greek xruso\s, "gold.", unless I give proofs by fact? But now, tell me, Mnesilochus, how much gold is requisite for you.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: There's occasion for two hundred pieces at once, to pay the Captain for Bacchis.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I'll find it you.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Then we have need of some for current expenses.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Aye, aye, I wish us to do each thing deliberately; when I've accomplished the one, then I'll set about the other. First, for the two hundred pieces, I shall direct my engine of war against the old gentleman. If with that engine I batter down the tower and the outworks, straight at the gate that instant I'll attack the old town and the new one; if I take it, then carry to your friends the gold in baskets, just as your heart wishes.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Our hearts are with you, Chrysalus.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Now, do you go in-doors to Bacchis, Pistoclerus, and quickly bring out--

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: A pen, some waxSome wax: This wax was to be used--not to be placed on the surface of the tablets, but in the manner of our sealing-wax, upon the strings with which the tablets were fastened., tablets, and some cord.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: I'll have them here this instant. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: What now are you about to do? Do tell me that.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Let a breakfast be prepared; there will be you two, and your mistress will make a third with you.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Just as you say.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Pistoclerus has no mistress?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: O yes, she's here; he's in love with the one sister, I with the other, both of the name of Bacchis.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What were you going to say? MNES. This; how we are to manageAre to manage: Mnesilochus is probably going to ask how they are about to arrange, when he is interrupted by Chrysalus, who then asks him what he was going to say, on which he answers that he was going to observe how many there would be at the entertainment..

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Where are your couchesYour couches: "Biclinium" is supposed to mean either a snug room fitted up with only two "lecti," or couches for reclining at meals, or else, perhaps with more probability, a couch formed for holding two guests, instead of three, as the common "triclinium" did. It is not unlikely that the use of these was especially adopted in houses of the character of that kept by Bacchis. laid out?

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Why o you ask that?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: So the matter stands; I wish to be informed. You know not what I am about to do, nor what a great exploit I shall attempt.

sp.speaker: MINES.
sp.p: Give me your hand, and follow me close, to the door. Peep in. CHRYSALUS looks in at the door of the house of BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Hurra! 'Tis a very pretty place, this, and exactly as I could wish it to be. Re-enter PISTOCLERUS, with pen and tablets.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: The things that you ordered--what's ordered for a good purpose is forthwith done by the obedient.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What have you brought?

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Everything that you bade me bring.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: to MNESILOCHUS. Do you take the pen at once, and these tablets.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: taking them. What then? CHRYS. Write there what I shall bid you; for I wish you to write for this reason, that your father may know the hand when he reads it. Write now.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: What shall I write?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Health to your father, in your own language. MNESILOCHUS writes.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Suppose he were to write "disease and death," in preference, that would be much better.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Don't you interrupt us.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: What you have ordered is now written on the wax.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Tell me in what terms.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: "Mnesilochus sends health to his father."

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Write this, too, quickly: "My father, Chrysalus is always and everywhere talking at me, and in no measured terms, because I gave you up the gold, and because I did not cheat you of it." MNESILOCHUS writes.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Stop till he has written it.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: It befits the hand of a lover to be active.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: I' faith, that hand is more active by far at lavishing than at writing.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Say on; that's written down.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: "Now, my dear father, do you henceforth be on your guard against him, for he is forming knavish plans to deprive you of the gold, and has declared that he will have it beyond a doubt." Write legibly.

sp.speaker: MINE.
sp.p: You only dictate. Writes. CHRYS. "And he promises that he will give this gold to me, for me to give away to naughty women, and to consume it and live like a GreekLive like a Greek: It has been before remarked, that the Greek mode of free living had passed into a proverb with the Romans, among whom a person of a licentious mode of life was said "congraecare," "to live like a Greek." Plautus forgets that the scene is at Athens. in dens of infamy. But, father, do you take care that he does not impose on you this day; I entreat you, do beware."

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Only say on.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Just write on, then.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Only say what I am to write

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: MNESILOCHUS writing. "But, father, what you promised me I beg that you will remember, that you will not beat him, but keep him in chains at your house at home." Do you give me the wax and cord forthwith. Come, fasten it, and seal it in an instant.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: sealing the tablets. Prithee, what use is there in this writing after such a fashion, that he is to give no credence to you, and to keep you in chains at home?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Because it pleases me so. Can't you possibly take care of your own self, and have no thought about me? In confidence in myself I undertook the task, and at my own peril do I carry on the matter.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: You say what's true.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Give me the tablets.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: giving them. Take them.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Give attention now; Mnesilochus, and you, Pistoclerus, do you take care that each of you goes at once and reclines on his couch with his mistress; so 'tis requisite; and on that same spot where the couches are now laid, do you forthwith commence to carouse.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: Anything else?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: This, and this especially: when you shall have once taken your places together, don't you arise anyhow, until the signal shall be given by me.

sp.speaker: PISTOCLERUS
sp.p: O skilful commander!

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You ought by this time to have taken your second draught.

sp.speaker: MNESILOCHUS
sp.p: Capital; let's go.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Do you take care of your duty, and I'll do mine. MNESILOCHUS and PISTOCLERUS go into the house.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: A tremendously great business am I undertaking, and I have my fears how in this one day I may accomplish it. But now I have occasion for the old blade to be fierce and savage at me. For it suits not this plan of mine that the old fellow should be calm when he has beheld me in his presence. I'll turn him aboutTurn him about: It is not improbable that this figure is borrowed from frying fish in the kitchen--"When he is done on one side, I'll turn him on the Other." this day, finely, if I live. I'll have him parched as well as ever pea was parchedPea was parched: "Frictum cicer," "parched vetches." Horace mentions these dainties. They were mostly purchased by the lower orders, and by slaves.. I'll walk before the door, that when he comes out, at once as he comes up, I may put the lettersPut the letter: His object is to entrap old Nicobulus in such a way that he must of necessity see his son in the company of the damsels, on which he will be inclined the more readily to believe the story that he has formed an intrigue with the wife of the Captain. in his hand. Stands near the door of BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: This is a matter of great vexation to me, that Chrysalus has thus escaped me this day.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: aside. I'm all right: the old fellow is in a passion. Now's my time for me to accost my man.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Who speaks hard by? Looking round. Why surely this is Chrysalus, I think.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: aside. I'll accost him. NICO. My honest servant, hail to you. What's doing now? How soon do I set sail for Ephesus, to bring back the gold home from Theotimus? What--silent? I swear by all the Gods, if I didn't love my son so much as to wish everything done for him that he desires that your sides should be wealed now right well with rods, and that in irons at the mill you should be lingering out your life. I've learnt of Mnesilochus all your wicked pranks.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Has he accused me? 'Tis very good; I am a bad one, I am a cursed one--a wicked one. Only reflect upon the matter. I'll utter not one word.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What? Hangdog, do you even threaten meEven threaten me: Nicobulus takes it for a threat, when he tells him "specta rem modo" "only reflect upon the matter."?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You'll find out before long what sort of man he is. He ordered me just now to carry this letter to you. He requested that that which is there written may be done.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Give it me,

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Take notice of the seal Gives him the tablets.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I know it. Where is he himself?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I don't know. I ought to know nothing now; I've forgotten everything. I know that I'm a slave; I know not even that which I do know. Aside. Now from the springe this thrush is catching at the worm; he'll be finely noosed this day, so well I've set the snare.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Stay here but a moment; I'll return to you directly, Chrysalus. Goes into his house.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: How he does dissemble with me; how ignorant I am of the business he's about. He has gone to fetch slaves from in-doors to bind me. The ship speeds prosperously on; finely, too, is this craft boarding itCraft boarding it: "Pulcre haec confertur ratis." This is a figure taken from naval affairs. Ships were said "conferri" when they closed together on commencing the engagement.. But I'll hold my tongue, for I hear the door opening.

div2.stage: Re-enter NICOBULUS, with SLAVES carrying fetters.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Artamo, do you fasten the hands of that fellow this very instant. The SLAVES bind him.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Pitch your fist into him if he mutters a word. To CHRYSALUS, pointing at the tablets. What does this letter say?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Why do you ask me? As I received it from him, so I've brought it sealed to you.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Come now, you rascal, have you not shamefully abused my son in your talk, because he gave me up that gold, and said that you would still take that gold away from me by some knavish trick?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Have I said so?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: You have.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What person is there, who says that I've said so?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Hold your tongue. No person says so; this letter which you have brought me accuses you. See, 'tis this that requests you to be chained. Points to the open tablets.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Ah! your son has been making a BellerophonA Bellerophon: He alludes to the hero Bellerophon, who, being accused by Sthenoboea of having made an attempt on her chastity, was sent by Proetus, King of Argos, with a letter to Iobates, in which he was desired to put the bearer to death. of me; I myself brought this letter, for the purpose that I might be bound. Be it so.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: This I am doing for this reason, because you persuade my son to live like a Greek with you, you thrice-dotted villain.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: aside. O fool, fool, you know not that you are at this moment on sale; and that you are standing on the very stoneOn the very stone: He alludes to the stone upon which the "praeco," or "auctioneer," stood with the slaves, when he sold them by auction. Only the cheapest and the least desirable of them were sold in this way. as the auctioneer puts you up.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: overhearing him. Answer me; who is selling me?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: He whom the Gods favourWhom the Gods favour: Menander has a sentence to the effect--"He whom the Gods love, dies young." Chrysalus tells Nicobulus that he is clearly no favorite of the Gods, or he would have died long since. dies in youth, while he is in his health, has his senses and judgment sound. This person (pointing to NICOBULUS), if any God had favoured him, ought to have been dead more than ten years--aye, more than twenty years ago. 'Tis for long, he has walked, a nuisance, on the earth; so devoid is he of either judgment or sense. He is of as much value as a rotten mushroom is.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Do you think that I am a nuisance to the earth? Away with him in-doors, and tie him tightly to the post. You shall never take away any gold from here.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: No, but you'll soon be giving it me.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I, give it you?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You'll be entreating me, too, of your own accord to receive it, when you shall come to know this accuser of mine, in how great danger and in what a dreadful situation he is. Then will you be offering his liberty to Chrysalus; but I certainly shan't accept it.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Tell me, source of mischief, tell me, in what danger is my son Mnesilochus.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Follow me this way; I'll soon let you know.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Where on earth shall I follow you?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Only three steps.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Aye, ten even.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Come, then, Artamo, do you open you this door out a very little way; softly, don't make it creak. The door of the house of BACCHIS is opened. That's enough. Now, step you hither. To NICOBULUS, who looks in. Do you see the entertainment?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: still looking in. I see Pistoclerus and Bacchis right opposite.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Who are upon that other couch?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: looking on the other side. Wretch that I am, I'm undone. CHRYS. Do you recognize that person?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I do recognize him.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Now tell me, if you please, does that woman seem of handsome appearance?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Very much so.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Well, do you take her to be a courtesan?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You are mistaken.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Who is she then, prithee?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You'll find out from me. indeed, you'll get no more information to-day.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: aloud. Is this Mnesilochus, the son of Nicobulus, by force to detain my own mistress? What proceeding is this?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: aside. This Captain's opportunely come for me.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: He doesn't consider that I am a soldier, but a woman, who cannot defend myself and mine. But may neither Bellona nor Mars ever put confidence in me, if I don't put him out of life, if I meet him, or if I don't make him lose possession of his existence.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Chrysalus, who's this that's threatening my son?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: This is the husband of that woman with whom he is now reclining.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What! The husband?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: The husband, I say.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Prithee, is she married then?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You'll know before very long.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Wretch that I am; I'm utterly undone.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: How now? Does Chrysalus seem such a villain to you? Come, chain me nowChain me now: He says this satirically pointing to his fetters, and do listen to your son. Didn't I tell you that you would discover what sort of person he is?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What shall I do now?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Order me at once to be released, if you please; for, if I'm not released, he'll just now be overpowering the young man in our presence.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: There's no gain that I should this day take so much delight in making, as I should in falling upon him as he reclines with her, so that I might kill them both.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: to NICOBULUS. Don't you hear what he says Why don't you order me to be released?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: to the SLAVES. Unbind him. I'm ruined; wretch that I am! I'm in a dreadful fright.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Then I'd make her, who publicly puts up her person for sale, not to say that she has got a person for her to laugh at.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: to NICOBULUS. You may make terms with him for a little money.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Make terms, then, I beg, for what you like; so that he mayn't, in our presence, fall upon the young man, or kill him outright.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Unless the two hundred Philippeans are repaid to me at once, I'll this instant swallow the lives of them both outright.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: to CHRYSALUS. Make terms with him, if you can; prithee, do make haste; agree for any sum you like.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I'll go, and do it carefully. Goes up to CLEOMACHUS. Why are you exclaiming so?

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Where's your master?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Nowhere; I don't know. Do you wish the two hundred pieces to be promised you at once, so as to make no riot or disturbance here?

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: There's nothing that I would desire more.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: And that I may heap many a curse upon you?

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Just as you please.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: aside. How the villain does cringe. To CLEOMACHUS. This is the father of Mnesilochus: follow rme; he shall promise it you. Do you ask for the gold. As to the rest, a word's enoughA word's enough: He says this, as he is afraid that if the conversation proceeds to any length, the old man will discover that she is not the Captain's wife.. They go up to NICOBULUS.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What has been done?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I've struck the bargain for two hundred Philippeans.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Well done! Goddess SalvationSalvation: It was a proverbial expression with the Romans to day that the Goddess "Salus," "health," or "salvation," "had saved," or "could not save" a person, as the case might be., thou hast saved me. Well, how soon am I to say I'll pay it?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: to CLEOMACHUS. Do you ask it of him; and to NICOBULUS do you promise it him.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I promise it. To CLEOMACHUS. Come, ask me.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Will you give me two hundred golden Philippean pieces, lawful money?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: "They shall be given," say: do answer him.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I'll give them.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Well, now, filthy fellow is there anything owing to you? Why are you plaguing him? Why are you frightening him about death? Both I and he wish you every ill luck. If you have a sword, still we have a spit at home; with which, in fact, if you provoke me, I'll make you more full of holes than a rat's skinA rat's skin: "Soricina naenia," "than a rat's ditty," literally. This was, no doubt, a proverbial saying, and speaking elliptically, was, perhaps, intended to apply to the squeaking of a rat when his body was pierced with holes while held fast in the trap. There is, however, great obscurity in the passage, and Commentators are very much divided as to its meaning. when caught in a trap. I' faith, for my part, some time since I found out what suspicion it was that tormented you; namely, that he was with that wife of yours.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Yes; and so he is.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: So may Jupiter, Juno, Ceres, Minerva, Hope, Latona, Ops, Virtue, Venus, Castor, Pollux, Mars, Mercury, Hercules, SummanusSummanus: It is not accurately known who the Deity Summanus was. Ovid, in his Fasti, B. 6, l. 731, speaks in uncertainty of him. He is, however, generally thought to have been the same with Pluto, who was so called as being "Summus Manum," "the Chief of the Spirits." Varro says that his worship was introduced by Tatius the Sabine, the Sun, Saturn, and all the Deities, prosper me, he neither reclines with her, nor walks, nor kisses, nor does that which is wont to be reported.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: aside. How he does swear! He's saving me, however, by his perjury.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Where then, at this moment, is Mnesilochus?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: His father has sent him into the country. And she has gone hence to the citadel, to see the temple of Minerva. The door's open now; go in, and see if he's there.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: I'll be off to the Forum next.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Or rather, by my troth, to very perdition.

sp.speaker: CLEOMACHUS
sp.p: Am I to demand this gold to-day?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Demand it, and go hang yourself; don't you suppose, you worthless fellow, that we shall be entreating of you. Exit CLEOMACHUS. He's taken himself off. Permit me, master, I entreat you by the immortal Gods, to go in-doors here to your son. Pointing to the house of BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: But why go in there?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: That with many words I may rebuke him, since after this fashion he has been going on this way.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Well, I beg you will do so, Chrysalus; and I entreat you not to spare him in your talking to him.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: And do you instruct even myself? Isn't it sufficient, if this day he shall hear from me more harsh things than ever Clinias heardClinias heard: He is alluding to a scene in some play, then well known, which is now lost. In it, Demetrius was probably severe upon Clinias. The Delphin editor thinks that this must have been a proverb. from Demetrius? Goes into the house of BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: This servant of mine is very like a running eye; if you have it not, you don't wish for it or desire it; if you have it, you can't keep off from rubbing it. But if he hadn't, by lucky chance, been here to-day, the Captain would have surprised Mnesilochus with his wife, and have killed him as an adulterer detected in the fact. Now, in a manner have I ransomed my son with the two hundred Philippeans which I have promised to give to the Captain; which, however, I shall not rashly pay him down, before I have met with my son. By my troth, I'll never rashly give credence in anything to Chrysalus. But I have a mind even once again to read over this letter; 'tis right that when a letter is sealed we should give credence to it. Goes into his house.

div2.stage: Enter CHRYSALUS from the house of BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: The two brothers, the sons of Atreus, are said to have done a most famous deed, when, with arms, and horses, and an army, and with chosen warriors, and with ships a thousand in number, after the tenth year, they subdued Pergamus, the native land of Priam, founded by hands divine. Not more decidedly did it fall by the engine of war, than I shall storm my master here, without a fleet, and without an army and so great array of soldiers. I have won, I have taken by storm this gold from his father for my master's son, in his amour. Now, before the old man comes here, I wish to lament until he does come out. O Troy! O my country! O Pergamus! O Priam! old man, you are undone, you, who'll be wretchedly and shockingly choused out of four hundred golden Philippeans. For those tablets, sealed on the one side and on the other, they are not tablets, but the horse which the Greeks sent, of wood. Pistoclerus is the EpeusIs the Epeus: Epeus was the builder of the wooden horse. When the treacherous Sinon was left behind, he lurked in the tomb of Achilles, or, according to some, in that of Palamedes.; from him were these received. Mnesilochus is the Simon left behind. Behold him! not in Achilles' tomb, but on a couch he reclines: he has Bacchis with him; just as the other formerly had the fire with which to give the signal; so now does she inflame himself. I am Ulysses, by whose advice they do these things. Then, the characters which there are written, are the soldiers in this horse, armed and of high courage. So even thus far has the matter prospered with me. This horse, too, will be making his attack, not on a citadel, but on a cofferNot on a citadel, but on a coffer: He puns on the resemblance of the words "arcem," a "citadel," and "arcam," a "chest" or "coffer." A ruin, a destruction, a cleaner-out of the old man's gold, will this horse prove this day. To this silly old man of ours, in fact, I give the name of Ilium; the Captain is Menelaüs; I, Agamemnon; I, too, am Ulysses, the son of Laërtes; Mnesilochus is AlexanderAlexander: Alexander was one of the names of Paris, the son of Priam., who will be the destruction of his father's fortunes; he has borne off the Helen, on whose account I am now carrying on the siege of Ilium. For there I have heard say that Ulysses was both bold and full of mischief, just as I am. I have been detected in my tricks--he, discovered in a beggar's guise, had almost perished, while he was spying out there the doings of the Trojans. Similarly has it happened to myself to-day. I have been bound, but by my devices I have redeemed myself; he, too, preserved himself by artifice. I have heard that there were three destiniesThere were three destinies: He has omitted three of the circumstances by which the downfall of Troy was to be precipitated--namely: if the horses of Rhesus should be captured before they had tasted of the pastures of Troy and the waters of Xanthus; if the bow and arrow of Hercules should be employed in the siege; and if one of the posterity of Achilles should be present, in all which circumstances the Greeks were eventually favoured. attending Troy, which were fatal to it; if the statue should be lost from the citadel; whereas the second was the death of Troilus; the third was when the upper lintel of the Phrygian gateThe Phrygian gate: This was the Scæan gate, near the tomb of King Laomedon should be demolished. Just so are there three fatalities for this Troy of ours, corresponding with those three; for, first of all, when, a short time since, as I told our old gentleman the lying story about his host, and the gold, and the bark, then, that instant, did I steal the statueSteal the statue: The Palladium was stealthily carried off from Troy by Ulysses and Diomedes. from the citadel. And even then two fatalities were remaining, and no further had I taken this city. Afterwards, when I carried the letter to the old man, then I killed my Troilus. When he supposed, just now, that Mnesilochus was with the Captain's wife, from that, with difficulty, did I disengage myself. And that danger do I compare to what they say, how that Ulysses, recognized by HelenRecognized by Helen: He alludes here, and in l. 951, to the occasion when Ulysses entered Troy as a spy, in the disguise of a beggar, on which occasion he was recognized by Helen., was betrayed to Hecuba. But as, in olden time, by his coaxing arts, he liberated himself from her, and persuaded her to let him go, so I, by my devices, have rescued myself from the danger, and have deceived the old man. Afterwards, I engaged with the blustering Captain, who, unarmed, takes cities with his words, and there I repulsed my man. Then I engaged in fight with the old gentleman; straightway by one lying device did I vanquish him; by one blow, in a moment, did I take the spoils away from him. He now will give the two hundred Philippean pieces to the Captain, which he has promised that he will give. Now, I have occasion for another two hundred, to be distributed when Ilium is taken, that there may be the usual draught of honeyed wineDraught of honeyed wine: "Mulsum." This was a mixture of wine and honey, flavoured with myrrh, cassia, nard, costum, or pepper. On the occasion of a triumph, the soldiers were treated to copious draughts of this mixture. with which the soldiers may celebrate their triumph. But this Priam is far superior to him of old. Not fifty sons only has he, but four hundred, and all choice ones, without a blemish; all these this day will I cut off at two single blows. Now, if there were any purchaser for this Priam of ours, I would sell the old fellow in the lumpIn the lump: "Coemptionalem senem." Those slaves were called "coemptionales" who, by reason of age or bad character, were so utterly worthless that they would fetch no price, and were consequently thrown into a lot with other slaves or property of real value., whom I have on sale the moment that J shall have taken the city. But, lo! I see our Priam standing before the door; I'll go and speak to him.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Pray, whose voice is it that sounds near me?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: O Nicobulus!

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: O, capital!

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Well, have you done aught of what I sent you upon?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What--ask you that? Step closer this way.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: coming nearer. Well, I do come closer.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I am an excellent pleader. By rebuking him, and by whatever hard language I really was able to think of, I forced the fellow to tears.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: He uttered not a word: crying, he listened in silence to what I was saying; in silence he wrote down on his tablets; these sealed he gave to me; he bade me deliver them to you. Gives him the tablets. But I am afraid that they sing to the same tune that the former ones did. Observe the seal, is it his?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I recognize it. I'd like to read them over. Goes to a distance.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Read them through. Aside. Now is the upper lintelThe upper lintel: He alludes to the Phrygian gate, which he has before mentioned in l. 955 being cut down, now is the destruction of Troy near at hand. The wooden horse is shaking it right cleverly.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Chrysalus, just step here while I am reading these through.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Prithee, what need is there for me to be near you?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: That you may know what's written here.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I don't care, and I don't wish to know.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Still, do come here.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What need is there?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I won't, I say.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: But I will, I say.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: What need is there?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Still do you only do that which I bid you.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I'll come. 'Tis right to do so; your own servant ought to be obedient at your command. Goes up to him.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: looking at the tablets. Heyday! he hasn't been sparingHasn't been sparing: By this expression he means that his son has written a very long letter, as he has been neither sparing of the wax for the table's, nor of the use of the "stylus" or pen. of his wax or pen. But whatever it is, I'm resolved to read it through. Attend to me, please, this very instant.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: When you choose, read on; I devote to you the attention of my ears.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: looking close. Bless me! the letters are small.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: To one, indeed, who cannot see well with his eyes but they are quite large enough for one who can see well.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Give your attention then. He reads. "Father, I beseech you, do give two hundred Philippeans to Chrysalus, if you wish me to be safe or alive for you----"

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: By my troth, really a very great mistake, I tell you.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: He hasn't first written the salutation to you.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: looking. I don't see it anywhere.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Even from its very commencement the letter is an impertinent one. If you are wise, you'll not give it; but at the best, if you give it him, why, let him find out some other porter for himself, if he is wise; for I won't carry it if you order me ever so much. I've been quite enough suspected as it is, when I was guiltless of a fault.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Listen on now, while I read through what's written. (Reading.) "I am ashamed, father, to appear before you in your presence; such disgraceful conduct of mine have I heard that you are aware of, that I have formed an intercourse with the wife of a strange Captain." By my troth, you are not joking there; for I have saved your life from the consequences of this foul deed with two hundred golden Philippeans.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: There's not a particle of these things but what I've told him.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: reading. "I confess that I have acted foolishly. But I beseech you, father, do not forsake me, if, in my folly, I have transgressed. Of fierce desires, and eyes uncontrolled, have I been; I have been urged on to do a deed of which I am now ashamed." It were proper, then, that you should have taken heed before you were ashamed.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: All these very same words did I say to him only just now.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: reading. "I beseech you, father, to consider that it is enough that Chrysalus has reproached me with many cutting words, and by his advice has made me a better man, so that 'tis right that you should return him sincere thanks."

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Is that written there?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Look and see, then you'll know. Shows him the letter.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: He that has so offended, how humble to all he is, and of his own accord.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: reading. "Now, father, if even yet I may be allowed to ask anything of you, do give me two hundred Philippean pieces, I do entreat you."

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: By my troth, now, not one even, if you are wise.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Let me read on. Reading. "In set formIn set form: Of course the oath would be the more solemn in such case. I have taken an oath that I would give this to the woman this day before nightfall, ere she leaves me. Now, father, have a care that I be not forsworn, and take me hence away from her as soon as you can, on whose account I have incurred so much loss and guilt. Take care and let not the two hundred pieces be a cause of annoyance to you; I will repay you innumerable times as much, if I live. Farewell, and do attend to these matters." Now, Chrysalus, what do you think?

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I won't give you one bit of advice this day, and I won't run the risk, that if any mistake is made, you should say that you had done it by my counsel. But, as I conceive, if I were in your place, I would rather give the gold than suffer him to be corrupted. There is a twofold choice consider which you would adopt; either to lose the gold, or for a lover to be forsworn. I neither order you, nor forbid you, nor do I persuade you.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I'm sorry for him.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: You don't do anything surprising--he is your son. If still more must be lost, 'tis better for it to go, than for this disgrace to be everywhere proclaimed.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: By my troth, I certainly had much rather he had been at Ephesus, so long as he was well, than that he had returned home. But why don't I hasten to get rid of that which is doomed to be squandered away? I'll bring you just now from in-doors twice two hundred Philippeans, both those which, a little time since, to my sorrow, I promised to the Captain, and these others. Wait there; I'll be out to you, Chrysalus, this instant. Goes into his house.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Troy is laid waste, the chiefs have razed Pergamus. I knew some time ago that I should be the ruin of Pergamus. I' faith I wouldn't dare make a bet with him who should say that I was deserving of severe torture; so great confusion am I making. But the door makes a noise; the plunder's being brought forth from Troy. For the present I'll hold my tongue. with the money in two bays.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Take you this gold, Chrysalus; go, carry it to my son. But I'll go hence to the market-place to pay this to the Captain.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: For my part, I'll not receive it; do you seek somebody at once to take it. I won't have it entrusted to me.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: But do take it; you're worrying me now. Holds it to him.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: For my part, I'll not take it.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: But, prithee do.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I am telling you what is the fact.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: You are delaying me.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I don't want, I say, the gold to be entrusted to me. At all events, find some person to keep a watch upon me.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: You're plaguing me.

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: Well, give it me, if it must be so. Holds out his hand.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: gives him the money. Take care of it. I'll be back here just now. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: CHRYSALUS
sp.p: I've taken care----that you shall be a most wretched old fellow; this is bringing an undertaking to a fair ending; even as it has proved my lot to go rejoicing, laden with the spoil. With safety to myself, and the city taken by stratagem, I now bring home my whole army unhurt. But, Spectators, don't you now be surprised that I don't go in triumph; 'tis such a common thing, I don't care for it. Still however, the soldiers shall be received with the usual honeyed wine. Now I'll carry off all this booty at once to the QuæstorTo the Quaestor: It was the custom of the Romans to deliver to the City Quaestor the plunder taken in war, to be employed in the public service. Here he means his young master, Mnesilochus.. Goes into the house of BACCHIS. Enter PHILOXENUS.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: The more I revolve it in my breast, what disturbances my son has raised, into what a course of life, and into what habits he unwittingly has headlong plunged himself, the greater is my concern, and the more do I dread lest he may be ruined or corrupted. I know it; I once was of the same age, and I did all these things; but in a quiet way. I was gay, I had my mistress, I drank, I feasted, I made presents, but still it was seldom I did so. The methods, too, please me not which I see parents in general employ towards their sons. I have determined to give some latitude to my son, that he may have some scope for his inclinations. I think that's right; but still, I don't wish him to give way too much to sloth and wantonness. Now I'm going to Mnesilochus, to see whether, as I requested, by his endeavours he has turned him for me to virtue and to sobriety; as, indeed, I am sure he has done if he has met him, of such a disposition is he by nature. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Whoever there are in any place whatsoever, whoever have been, and whoever shall be, in time to come, fools, blockheads, idiots, dolts, sots, oafs, lubbersOafs, lubbers: "Blennus" means, properly, "dirty-nosed," and thence "a driveller," "an idiot." "Bucco" was "one who had large puffed-out cheeks," which was considered to be the mark of a blockhead or foot., I singly by far exceed them all in folly and absurd ways. I'm undone. I'm ashamed of myself; that I at this time of life should disgracefully have been twice made a fool of! The more I think of this confusion which my son has made, the more am I incensed. I'm ruined, and I'm utterly destroyed; I'm distracted in every possible way. All plagues harass me, by all modes of death do I perish. This day has Chrysalus rent me in pieces; Chrysalus has plundered wretched me; he, the villain, by his clever tricks, has shaved, to the very quick, simple me, just as he has pleased. For the Captain says that she is a Courtezan, whom that fellow said was his wife; and he has informed me of everything, as each particular happened; how that she had been hired by him for this year; how that that much gold was left to be repaidLeft to be repaid: This passage is rather obscure; but it seems to mean that Bacchis had been engaged for a year by the Captain, and that having received the whole sum when the original agreement was made, she had arranged to repay the Captain a sum proportionate to the time that was wanting to complete the year engaged for., which I, most simple man, had promised him. 'Tis this, this, I say, through which my breast boils with indignationBoils with indignation.: "Peracescit." Literally, "turns sour."; 'tis this, in fine, by which I am distracted; that I, at my time of life, should be made a fool of, aye, by Heaven, so made a very sport of, and with my hoary head and white beard, that wretched I should be bamboozled out of my gold. Undone am I, inasmuch as this slave of mine has dared in this way to set not the value of a nutshell upon me. And I--if any other way I had lost a greater sum--I should have taken it less amiss, and have deemed it less of a loss to me. Enter PHILOXENUS.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: as he enters. For sure, some person, I know not who, seems to be talking near to me. But who's this I see? Really, 'tis the father of Mnesilochus.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Hah! I see a partner in affliction. Save you, Philoxenus!

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: And you; whence are you betaking yourself?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: From a place whence comes a wretched and a luckless mortal.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Why, troth, I'm surely on the earth, the spot where it befits a wretched and a luckless mortal to be.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: We now, as we are of like age, are meeting with similar fortunes.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: So it is. But as to yourself, what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I' faith, mine's the same mishap as your own.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Does this misfortune in any way relate to your son?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Such is the fact.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: The same disease exists in my own breast.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Aye, and that very worthy fellow, Chrysalus, has been ruining my son, myself, and all my fortunes.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Pray now, what is this mishap of yours about your son?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: You shall know: together with your own son he's undone; both of them are keeping mistresses alike.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I have seen them.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Ah! wretch that I am! I'm ruined outright.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Why do we hesitate a moment to knock and to call them both hither out of doors.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: I don't object.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: knocks at the door of the house of BACCHIS. Hallo there! Bacchis! Bid the door to be opened this instant, if you please, unless you had rather the door and the posts be knocked to bits with hatchets.

div2.stage: Enter FIRST BACCHIS and SECOND BACCHIS from the house.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Who is it that calls out my name with such a noise and tumult, and is knocking so hard at the door?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I and this person here. Pointing to PHILOXENUS.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Pray, what's the matter now? Who has been driving these sheepDriving these sheep: She calls them sheep, probably, because of their venerable appearance; though she afterwards remarks that they are but dirty sheep. Perhaps, too, it was the custom among ladies of this class, in cant phrase to call those "sheep" who could stand fleecing; a point on which it will be found in the dialogue that they exchange remarks. "Goats" would have been a more appropriate name, under the circumstances for the old sinners. to us?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: These most shocking hussies call us sheep.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: Their shepherd's asleep, as they come straying thus from the flock.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: But, i' faith, they are not white; they both look dirty.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: Because they have both been shorn just now.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: How they seem to be laughing at us.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Let them, just as long as they please.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Don't you think that these sheep are shorn three times a year?

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: I' faith, to-day one of them has been already shorn twice, that's sure.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: They are old and fleecelessOld and fleeceless: "Mina ovis" was a sheep that had no wool on its belly. It is hard to say why this name was given to it. If the word "mina" had signified a certain coin, and not a sum of money merely, we might have supposed it alluded to the smoothness of the coin., both of them.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: But I think they have been in good plight once.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Prithee, do you see how they are looking with a sheep's eye at us?

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: By my troth, I really do believe they are without any ill design.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: This happens to us deservedly, for having come here.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Well, let them be driven in-doors to foldBe driven in-doors to fold: "Cogantur." Literally, "let them be driven within." "Cogor" was the term applied to penning or folding sheep of cattle..

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: I don't know what occasion there is for that, as they have neither milk nor wool. Let them stand as they are. Of whatever value they have been, they are now out of date; all their fruit has fallen off them by this. Don't you see, how, straying unattended, they are ranging about at liberty? Why, I fancy that they must be dumb with age; they don't bleat even, though they are absent from the rest of the flock. They seem both silly and worthless.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Let's return in-doors, sister.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Stay where you are, both of you; these sheep want you.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: Why, surely this is a prodigy; sheep are addressing us with a human voice.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: These sheep will return you the heavy and great injury which they owe to you.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: If you owe me aught, I forgive it you; keep it to yourself; I'll never demand it of you. But what is the reason that you are threatening mischief to us?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Because they say that our two lambs are shut up here. Pointing to the house.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: And besides those lambs, my dog is there concealed that bitesThat bites: He alludes to his having been bitten by Chrysalus.. If they are not now produced to us and sent out of the house, we shall be furious rams; we shall attack you forthwith.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Sister, I have something to say to you in private.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: How now, prithee? They go apart.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Whither are they going?

sp.speaker: FIRST BACCHIS
sp.p: Sister, I give to you that old fellow that's farthest off, that you may have him cleverly smoothed down; I'll now attack this other one that's angry; if we can only entice them here indoors.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: I'll manage my task with cleverness, although 'tis to caress an old skeleton.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Take care and do your best.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: Be quiet; do you do yours; I'll manage what I have said.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Why are these two women holding a council here in private?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: What say you, my good fellow----?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What would you with me?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: I really am ashamed to tell you a certain thing.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What is it that you're ashamed about?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Still, as you are a person, a friend of mine, I'm determined to entrust you with what I could wish. Whispers. I'm good for nought.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I've known that this long time; but tell me why you're good for nought?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: I've been terribly touched with birdlime: troth, my heart is pierced by the goad.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I' faith, 'twere much better if your flanks were goaded, you worthless fellow. But what is it? Although I suspect that I myself pretty well know already what it is; still, I should even like to hear it from yourself.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Do you see that woman? Pointing to the SECOND BACCHIS.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I see her.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: She's not an uncomely person.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Troth, but she is decidedly uncomely; and you are a good-for-nothing fellow.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Why more? I'm in love.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: You, in love?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: 'Pon honorPon honor: *nai ga/r. This Greek phrase was, no doubt, used as a cant or off-hand mode of expression, just as on similar occasions we adopt the French "oui" or "vraiement," "yes," "decidedly.".

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: And do you, you rotten creature, presume to become a lover at your time of life?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Because it's a disgrace.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: What need of words? I am not vexed with my son, nor yet is it right you should be vexed with yours: if they are in love, they do wisely.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Follow me this way. They approach the old men.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: See, they are moving at last, these allurers and enticers to disgrace. To the women. How now? Do you this instant restore us our sons and my servant, or am I to try rougher means with you?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Won't you away with you? You surely are not a man, to address a pretty woman so rudely in that fashion.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Most worthy old gentleman, by whatsoever is upon the earth, let me entreat this of you, that you will cease to attack this error with such great vehemence.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: If you don't away with you, although you are so handsome, I'll be doing you some great mischief just now.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: I shall endure it; I don't apprehend that any blow that you can give, will cause me any pain.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: How smooth of speech she is. O me! I am in alarm.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: aside. He's more calm already. Aloud. Step this way with me in-doors; and there, if you choose, correct your son. Takes his arm.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Avaunt from me, abomination! Shakes her off.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Do, my love, let me prevail upon you.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: You, prevail upon me? 2nd

sp.speaker: FIRST BACCHIS
sp.p: For sure, I shall prevail, at all events, upon this gentleman. Pointing PHILOXENUS.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Yes, I beg of you to show me in-doors.

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: What a dear man you are.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: But do you know on what condition you are to show me in-doors?

sp.speaker: 2nd BACCHIS
sp.p: That you are to be with me.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: You mention all that I desire.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I have seen wicked men; but not one worse than yourself.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: I am as I am.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: to NICOBULUS. Step this way in-doors with me, where you may be elegantly received with viands, wine, and unguents.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Enough, enough now of your banquets; it matters not to me how I'm received. My son and Chrysalus have choused me out of four hundred Philippeans. If I don't surely this day put him to the torture, may I never receive as large a sum again.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: What, pray, if half the gold is paid you back? Will you go in-doors here with me, and so control your feelings as to forgive them their faults?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: He'll do it. Takes his arm.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Certainly not--I won't--I don't care--let me alone, now. Shakes him off. I had rather punish them both.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Take you care, you good-for-nothing man, that through your own fault you don't lose even that which the favouring Gods offer you. One half of the gold is offered; take it, and carouse, and enjoy yourself with your partner.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What, am I to carouse in that very place where my son is being corrupted?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: You must carouse there.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Am I to be the witness of it when she is reclining with him at table?

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Nay, so far as I'm concerned, i' faith, I'll recline at table with your own self.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: My head does itch soDoes itch so: Being in doubt what to do, he scratches his head, and then tries to turn it off by saying, "Bless me, how my head does itch.". Aside. I'm a ruined man--I can scarce deny her.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: And has it not before this come into your mind, that if, while you live, you enjoy yourself, that, i' faith, is for no very long time; and that, if you lose the present day, it can never return to you after you are dead?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: What are you to do? Do you even ask it?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: I should like, and yet I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: What are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Lest I should be exposed before my son and my servant.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Pray now, my honey; such things do happen. He's your own son; whence do you suppose that he is to have money, except that only which you give him yourself? Let me obtain pardon of you for them both.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: aside. How she does work her way. She's now prevailing on me against that which I was quite resolved upon.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: I will love you, and embrace you.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Through your doing, and for your sake am I corrupted.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: I certainly had rather 'twere for your own than for mine.

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: Come then, however that may be, although it is to my disgrace, I'll submit; I'll induce my feelings to do so.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: Have I that solemnly promised?

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: What I have once said, I will not alter.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: The day wears apace. Come into the house, to take your places at table: your sons are expecting within----

sp.speaker: NICOBULUS
sp.p: How soon, in fact, we may be dead, d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: 'Tis evening, already; come, follow us.

sp.speaker: PHILOXENUS
sp.p: Lead us in like bondsmenLike bondsmen: "Addicti" were those who were made the slaves of their creditors; being thus by law deprived of their liberty until they had paid their debts.. They go into the house.

sp.speaker: 1st BACCHIS
sp.p: to the SPECTATORS. Right cleverly are these persons entrappedThese persons entrapped: The two old men, at this moment, would form a good companion picture to the Elders, who solicited the chastity of Susanna. themselves, who for their sons had laid a snare. Goes in.

sp.speaker: The COMPANY The company: The whole company of actors (Caterva) now comes forward, and chant or repeat the moral of the Play which has just been acted. of COMEDIANS
sp.p: Had not these old men been worthless from their youth upwards, they would not, with their hoary heads, have this day done an action so disgraceful; nor, indeed, should we have represented this, if we had not, before this, seen it happen that fathers became the rivals of their sons in the houses of procurers. Spectators, we wish you Farewell! and that you will grant us loud applause.
